content:
You don't login to Thunderbird but to your email provider's server. All you can do is to tell Thunderbird to remember your account password, so that you won't be prompted every time the password is needed.

But I connot log into Thunderbird and the settings all seem okay.

You're just stating that there is a problem, but you're not telling what the problem is. Neither you're stating your OS and Thunderbird version. Please provide more information about your problem.
creator: christ1

content:
The saved passwords are nothing like the password I had been using.

Some email providers such as Gmail, AOL, Yahoo, and others are using OAuth2 authentication. That means Thunderbird stores an OAuth2 authentication token, and not the actual account password. The token expires at some point, and you'll be prompted to re-authenticate. I'd assume you do use OAuth2 authentication.
creator: christ1

content: Thank you. This confirms my caution in removing those stored passwords. It does not explain the reason for thunderbird not asking for my password any longer and how I can restore having to input my password. Thank you very much for finding an answer for me.
creator: chrisjae

content:
It does not explain the reason for thunderbird not asking for my password any longer and how I can restore having to input my password.

If your account uses OAuth2 authentication:

  • delete the OAuth2 authentication token Thunderbird has remembered
  • restart Thunderbird
  • re-authenticate and make sure not to check the box 'Remember password'
  • have fun with re-authentication every time Thunderbird starts
creator: christ1

content: First, I am a novice at Linux, but typically, the default browser is set in the OS, not the email client. At least that's how it works in Windows. Thunderbird just invokes to default browser, but does not set it. This article may (or may not) be useful: https://linuxconfig.org/how-to-set-browser-environment-variable-on-linux
creator: davidsk

content:

That solved my problem, finally. I was being fooled by Firefox itself - apparently the "Firefox is your default browser" setting and confirmation (view image) is irrelevant.

content: Ouch! That hurts. Here's a tip for the future. with 102 going forward, there is an easy backup with tools>export if profile doesn't exceed 2 gig. Otherwise, copying c:\users\<yourID>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird is good, but done ONLY when thunderbird is not running. Also, I see many failed restores because the backups were done (with various backup software) when Thunderbird was running, which always produces a corrupted backup.

creator: royzee1

content:
I just hope you took Davids advice to throw your copy of mozbackup.

It has got to the point now as it has not seen any update since March 29th, 2011. I would now consider it dangerous. It has no concept of newer file formats and as such anything but a Full copy is not going to be complete. It has no idea about profile per install so restoring is really a gamble.

The full profile is simply copied and zipped by mozbackup. Then given an extension of whatever it uses for it's files. But they are zip files. So this is identical to the profile export on the tools menu as Thunderbird exports the profile and zips it.

Given it's age, I would also suspect mozbackup will also barf on profiles over 2Gb.

Do this: - install thunderbird and thenexit it. - now copy the backup to same location on new pc, although user id may be different

- start thunderbird and everything should be there.

NOTE: the tools>export and tools>import are only for smaller profiles.

content: DKIM and SPF are settings to be done on your email host. They are needed to legitimize your domain. For example, if you have the domain ronsplace and the webhost is bluehost, then when you send email the smtp server is is one of bluehost's. To ensure it isn't spam, another email server may probe to see if bluehost is set up to serve ronsplace, or whether ronsplace is a spam domain. So, if you're sending mail from your domain and receiving DKIM and SPF errors, contact your web host.

content:
I am going to ask and probably regret doing so, but why not just use pop in the first place? Even if that means having the account added twice once as POP and once as IMAP (something I do for one of my accounts)

However some observation that may of may not help.

  • Change your filter to function after junk classification. This appears to fix a lot of odd issues with filter on IMAP account as the filtering can start before the body is fully downloaded. Junk delays the execution and allows things to function better. I have no idea beyond that.
  • The use of To in your filter is also concerning. Mail you receive as CC of BCC is not addressed to you in the to field, so it will not be copied. Using a custom header in the filter and specifying Delivered-To: will give a much more complete list.
  • Finally you should be using contains, not is. Mail is routinely addresses as follows, so the from in a mail client will show Matt, not the email address 
 To: Matt<unicorn.doctor@gmail.com>

That would not match an "IS" as it is more than the email address.

content:
Well the first thing would be to not use apple editors to generate your signature. Use the Thunderbird write window.

The second thing I observe immediately is the choice of a 10 pixel font. Really tiny that.

The third and perhaps most important thing I am seeing is you are trying to control the font size in something that should be left alone in the vast majority of cases.

Thunderbird uses the HTML font sizes from extra small to extra large because it is rare that two displays will share a scaling factor. This is especially so as Apple and 4k monitors use a pixel doubling approach and present special issues for rendering HTML as a result.

So you specify the font as "Normal" and when it gets where it is going the receiving rendering engine scales the font to largely what is appropriate for the device. The scaling being different on a 5" phone screen to a 65" television.

Then we get things like Microsoft office and others that try and enforce rather silly things like points into email. A point is a 1/64th of an inch, an absolute value on a non absolute render size. This generally means another lot of abstracts while some software tries to turn this absolute into something that scales without looking clownish.

So if you want everyone so see something similar get rid of all the font sizing in pixels. That HTML is full of it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Hi Matt, Thank you for your very detailed response.

I'm going to try and clarify my query and perhaps you will be able to help me implement it.

1. I'm content to let HTML do its thing on the respondent's receiving end. I'll assume that their scaling is sane and not of particular interest to me.

2. Most full HTML email I receive displays quite well.

3. On my end (the composition end) I'd like to adjust my composition display so I see a font size range (cruddly printed font size) of, say, 9 to 16 points (convert to px, if you will), with with "medium" being 10 or 12 pts.

4. What I'm confused about:

a. Settings->Composition->HTML style: Does this setting only affect what I see in the composition window? Or does it affect the size of text the recipient sees, or both?

b. Settings->General->Language & Appearance:

c. Would I use this setting to control what I see in incoming HTML email? Or does it only set the font size relative size I see in the composition window?

d. Just what exactly does each of the above two settings affect?

4. Other matters:

a. I preferreading plain-text message in Helvetica/Ariel font, _not_ monospace ,so I have Settings->General->Plain Text Messages set to "Regular"; "Regular." The problem here for me is that when I move from a received HTML message to a received plain-text message, the plain-text message text is quite large, so I've been using the macOS <"cmd" + "+"> or <"cmd" + "-" to adjust the font size.

5. Question: Is their a way to force the size of the variable-space font displaying the plain-text message? Comment: The above occurs whether the plain-text is between and or simply message body of plain-text. It also doesn't matter whether the message is plain old ascii or plain old ascii encoded in base64 with or wi/o HTML tags.

6. Finally, I note that T-bird resets whatever <cmd+> or <cmd–> controls. Is there a way to keep whatever is occurring in this domain constant between T-bird invocations?

Really appreciative for your help and the over and beyond explanations you've already provided! (I do want to stick with T-bird!)
creator: jeffb4

content: Correction on my previous Question 5: Didn't know your message software "eats" HTML tags, so the sentence in the "Comment" should read "The above occures whether the plain-text is between "HTML-begin tag" and "HTML-end tag". Just fyi :-)

content:
Disable your email antivirus scanner and watch things get moving. (I hope)

Thunderbird is reaching out an getting the settings, that indicates there is no firewall issue, or if there is it is port specific. This can be the case, but rarely on consumer equipment. That it then can not log in using the setting it found usually indicates an antivirus scanning email, or encrypted connections, being a fly in the ointment.

Unfortunately most of the current crop of anti virus product are less than conducive to doing anything but browsing the web
